Award.AwardTitle: When Can We Cluster Data? Improved Conditions for Perfect Recovery and Numerical Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
The clustering procedure is ubiquitous in science and engineering, especially in analysis of massive data sets and complex networks. The purpose of clustering is to divide a given data set into groups of similar items, called clusters. Although many heuristics for clustering exist (and are widely used), the theoretical properties of this learning task are less well-understood. Relatively few theoretical analyses have been performed establishing conditions under which we may expect to successfully cluster data. The goal of this project is to establish realistic theoretical guarantees for clustering, both in terms of data amenable to clustering as well as in the development of effective, computationally efficient algorithms. The project will facilitate interdisciplinary research via applications in image processing, astronomy and physics, mathematical biology, social network analysis, and high-dimensional statistics. The project will also provide educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students through the development of new courses focusing on the interaction of machine learning and large-scale optimization, interdisciplinary undergraduate research programs, and K-12 outreach programs.

The project focuses on two main research thrusts. The first concerns the generalization of average case analyses and theoretical guarantees for perfect recovery for convex relaxations of model problems for clustering, such as the densest submatrix localization and graph partition problems. The goal of these analyses is to extend the existing state of the art to probabilistic models for data that are more representative of data observed in practical applications. Extensive average planted case analyses will be performed to establish computational and information-theoretic bounds for perfect recovery under generalizations of the stochastic block model. The second thrust will focus on the design, analysis, and implementation of numerical methods for large-scale semidefinite and nonlinear optimization, with specific focus on the algorithms for model problems for clustering and classification. Theoretical convergence analysis and numerical simulation will be performed to illustrate the efficacy of the methods. This project is jointly funded by the Computational Mathematics program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development and analysis of novel optimization methods for clustering, classification, and dimension reduction. While popular heuristics for these tasks often perform very well in practice, there  are relatively few theoretical guarantees for their accuracy. The goal of this project was to partially address this knowledge gap.

New model problems for the maximum clique, densest submatrix, and graph clustering and biclustering problems were proposed and analysed. We establish new recovery guarantees providing conditions for recovery of hidden structures within random graphs using relaxations of these models. These guarantees generalize existing results, widening our understanding of when these machine learning problems are solvable. For example, we establish conditions for perfect recovery of the maximum clique in a random graph containing many cliques; earlier results were limited to graphs containing only the planted clique and diversionary edges and nodes. Further these results establish perfect recovery of potentially much smaller cliques, subgraphs, clusters, etc., than previously discovered.

Algorithms for efficient solution of these learning tasks were also developed and applied to a range of real data. For example, we performed novel analyses of EEG data, in collaboration with neuroscientists and communications experts, to identify and classify patterns in visual comprehension of language.

In total, four peer reviewed papers partially supported by this grant have been published, with more in preparation or review. Software implementations of the algorithms developed during this funded research have been released, in an effort to facilitate reproducibility of our research and to encourage adoption of our methods. Over 10 invited research talks were given on topics pertaining to this grant.

Over the course of this grant, 6 PhD students were supported. Three have successfully defended their dissertation research; one graduated August 2022, the next in August 2023, and the last will graduate in August 2024 having completed all degree requirements. The remaining PhD students are scheduled to complete their degree requirements, including dissertation research within the next two years. All six students belong to underrepresented groups in mathematics. A further 6 masters student projects were supervised during the funding period, along with several undergraduate research projects.
